VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
- 2023 Interim: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting period as
a result of the Interim inspection completed on 10/31/2023. This CAP contained
one violation of CCI Rule 400.4113(1)(i) in that there were three out of forty-two
new employees that did not have the documentation of verification the employee
has not been determined to be perpetrator of child abuse or neglect within the
appropriate time frame. The CAP contained action items to ensure that invidudals
were properly screened for child abuse and neglect clearances in the approved
amount of time prior to hire.
- Special Investigation 2024SIC0001467 with CAP approval date of 07/23/24 was
a result of a violation for staff not following the facility's supervision policy while out
on an outing. The facility had terminated the staff that was involved in the situation
and completed a scenario base training with staff about supervision requirements
when off grounds. The facility is currently complying with CAP action steps, and
DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
- Special Investigation 2024SIC0001552 with CAP approval date of 08/28/24 was
a result of a violation for staff not following the facility's supervision policy while
transporting youth to a community outing. The facility provided coaching to the
staff involved, completed a team meeting with staff about supervision for transport
and created a vehicle usage log. The facility is currently complying with the CAP
action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted
concerns.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility’s
budget and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Over the past year there has
been a significant reduction in investigation compared to years prior. The facility

has worked significantly to reduce these numbers through training, coaching and
supervision. The Chief Administrator reported the biggest barrier this past year has
been the market limitations on the quantity and quality of available staff hires into
programming. Residential Administrators meet with leadership partners at least
twice per month to discuss concerns and to make collaborative decisions
regarding practices that impact the facility.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or concerns
were raised. The staff reported feeling supported by direct supervisors as well as
administration. The staff reported they feel well versed on de-escalation trainings
to help support the youth.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and all youth reported
feeling safe at the facility. Each youth reported having a positive relationship with
at least one staff at the facility that they can go to if they have concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on October 14, 2024.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
